CLINTON_199_2.input:
CLINTON: "which may prove to be an intelligence benefit
we've got to do everything we can to vacuum up intelligence from Europe, from the Middle East
That means we've got to work more closely with our allies, and that's something that Donald has been very dismissive of
We're working with NATO, the longest military alliance in the history of the world, to really turn our attention to terrorism
We're working with our friends in the Middle East, many of which, as you know, are Muslim majority nations
Donald has consistently insulted Muslims abroad, Muslims at home, when we need to be cooperating with Muslim nations and with the American Muslim community
They're on the front lines
They can provide information to us that we might not get anywhere else
They need to have close working cooperation with law enforcement in these communities, not be alienated and pushed away as some of Donald's rhetoric, unfortunately, has led to"

cqs.cq: What if the close working cooperation with Muslim nations and communities that Clinton emphasizes could cause a significant increase in intelligence gathering, but at the same time, lead to increased community tensions due to Donald's rhetoric?

Do you have any evidence that your approach to intelligence gathering from Muslim-majority nations would be more effective if not for Donald's alleged "insults" and rhetoric, considering the complexities of international cooperation?

If we're seeking to gather intelligence from Muslim-majority nations, does that not imply that their cultural and religious perspectives could be a valuable asset in the fight against terrorism, rather than a liability to be marginalized?

If we're seeking intelligence from Muslim-majority nations to combat terrorism, does President Clinton's emphasis on close cooperation with the American Muslim community contradict the negative rhetoric and actions towards Muslims that President Donald has displayed?

CLINTON_1_2.input:
CLINTON: "If you help create the profits , you should be able to share in them , not just the executives at the top
I want us to do more to support people who are struggling to balance family and work
I 've heard from so many of you about the difficult choices you face and the stresses that you 're under
let 's have paid family leave , earned sick days
Let 's be sure we have affordable child care and debt-free college
How are we going to do it
We 're going to do it by having the wealthy pay their fair share and close the corporate loopholes
we tonight are on the stage together , Donald Trump and I
it 's good to be with you
We 're going to have a debate where we are talking about the important issues facing our country
You have to judge us , who can shoulder the immense , awesome responsibilities of the presidency , who can put into action the plans that will make your life better
I hope that I will be able to earn your vote on November 8th"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on sharing profits and closing corporate loopholes causes a shift in the economic burden, then would it ultimately affect the ability of the wealthy to continue funding their philanthropic efforts and charitable causes?

Do you have a concrete, detailed plan, backed by a reputable source, to demonstrate how your proposed policies, such as paid family leave and debt-free college, would be implemented and funded, without relying on the wealthy paying their "fair share" and closing corporate loopholes?
If a politician advocates for equal benefits for long-term contributors, why should executives at the top, who may have profited from the same system, be exempt from sharing in those benefits?
If the wealthy are expected to pay their fair share and close corporate loopholes, why should they still be able to accumulate wealth at the expense of those struggling to balance family and work?

CLINTON_21.input:
CLINTON: "nine million people lost their jobs
Five million people lost their homes
$ 13 trillion in family wealth was wiped out
Now , we have come back from that abyss
it has not been easy
we 're now on the precipice of having a potentially much better economy
the last thing we need to do is to go back to the policies that failed us in the first place
Independent experts have looked at what I 've proposed
looked at what Donald 's proposed
I intend to get it done
Take clean energy
Some country is going to be the clean- energy superpower of the 21st century
Donald thinks that climate change is a hoax perpetrated by the Chinese
I think it 's real"

cqs.cq: What if prioritizing short-term economic recovery over long-term environmental sustainability causes the country to miss the opportunity to become the clean-energy superpower of the 21st century?

Do you have any expert opinion that supports the notion that the current economic recovery is solely a result of reversing previous policies, rather than a combination of various factors and initiatives?

If the economic devastation of a global crisis warrants caution against repeating past failures, why does Clinton's stance on climate change seem to dismiss the potential for long-term consequences as a "hoax" by a nation rather than a pressing global issue?

If a president's economic policies led to such significant losses, yet he now advocates for a return to those policies, does this reflect a lack of accountability and willingness to learn from past mistakes?

CLINTON_223_1.input:
CLINTON: "Let 's talk about two important issues that were briefly mentioned by Donald
first , NATO
NATO as a military alliance has something called Article 5
you know the only time it 's ever been invoked ?
After 9/11 , when the 28 nations of NATO said that they would go to Afghanistan with us to fight terrorism
something that they still are doing by our side
With respect to Iran , when I became secretary of state , Iran was weeks away from having enough nuclear material to form a bomb
They had mastered the nuclear fuel cycle under the Bush administration
They had built covert facilities
They had stocked them with centrifuges that were whirling away
we had sanctioned them"

cqs.cq: What if the invocation of Article 5 by NATO, which demonstrated collective defense and support, could have a significant effect on the global response to Iran's nuclear program and potentially prevent the production of a nuclear bomb?

Does the historical context of NATO's Article 5 invocation after 9/11 and the concerns about Iran's nuclear program under the Bush administration serve as a valid precedent for the current geopolitical tensions between the US and Iran?

If NATO invoked Article 5 after 9/11, which involved military action, why would the same alliance not invoke it in response to a nation's nuclear development, which also poses a significant threat to global security?

If NATO invoked Article 5 in response to 9/11, but the threat of Iran's nuclear program was deemed significant enough to warrant sanctions, why was the response to the latter not more robust, considering the potential consequences of nuclear proliferation?

CLINTON_223_2.input:
CLINTON: "I voted for every sanction against Iran when I was in the Senate
it was n't enough
I spent a year-and-a-half putting together a coalition that included Russia and China to impose the toughest sanctions on Iran
 we did drive them to the negotiating table
my successor , John Kerry , and President Obama got a deal that put a lid on Iran 's nuclear program without firing a single shot
That 's diplomacy
That 's coalition-building
That 's working with other nations
That 's not good judgment"

cqs.cq: What if the sanctions imposed by Clinton were actually a cause of Iran's willingness to negotiate, then wouldn't that undermine the claim that her successor and President Obama were solely responsible for the successful outcome?

Does your record of supporting sanctions against Iran, which you described as "diplomacy," not "bad judgment," demonstrate a consistent approach to foreign policy or a selective interpretation of past events?

If imposing sanctions on Iran through a coalition with Russia and China, resulting in a nuclear deal without military action, can be considered a successful example of diplomacy, why is the current administration's approach to international relations seen as ineffective?

If CLINTON was able to effectively negotiate a deal with Iran without using military force, why is his approach with North Korea being praised while his own experience is being dismissed as a "bad judgment"?

CLINTON_225.input: CLINTON: "That is not the right temperament to be commander-in- chief , to be taunted"

cqs.cq: What if the temperament of a president is one that can be easily taunted, then how can they effectively navigate the complexities of international diplomacy?

Do you have any credible sources that support the claim that temperament is the sole determining factor in a president's ability to hold the office, rather than a combination of leadership skills, policy expertise, and character?
If a president's temperament can be criticized for being too emotional, why would that not be a valid concern for a candidate who has been publicly taunted and bullied throughout their career?
If a commander-in-chief's temperament can be judged by how he reacts to taunts, then how does that reflect on a president's ability to handle the pressures of international diplomacy?

CLINTON_231.input:
CLINTON: "in fact , his cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons is so deeply troubling
That is the number-one threat we face in the world
it becomes particularly threatening if terrorists ever get their hands on any nuclear material"

cqs.cq: What if a cavalier attitude towards nuclear weapons by a world leader becomes a cause for terrorists to gain access to nuclear material, thereby potentially leading to catastrophic effects on global security?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that a president's attitude towards nuclear weapons is a more significant threat to global security than the potential acquisition of nuclear material by terrorists?

If the threat of nuclear weapons being in the hands of terrorists is the number-one threat we face in the world, why does Clinton's administration not prioritize disarmament and non-proliferation efforts as much as it does the military's ability to counter such threats?

If the threat of nuclear terrorism is the number-one threat we face in the world, then shouldn't President Clinton's cavalier attitude about nuclear weapons be seen as a reckless endorsement of that threat?

CLINTON_235.input:
CLINTON: "It 's a good one , though
It well describes the problem"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of any of the pieces of information Clinton has influence the decisions they make about whether to describe the problem accurately?

Do you have any scientific evidence or credible sources that support your claim that the issue you're describing is accurately captured by the phrase you mentioned, or are you relying on anecdotal or personal experiences?
If systemic injustices and inequalities have been perpetuated for so long, does that not make the current state of affairs a reflection of what has been described as a perpetual problem?
If Clinton finds it a good description of the problem, does that imply he also supports the violent and oppressive nature it portrays?

CLINTON_244_2.input:
CLINTON: "If he 's going to criticize a deal that has been very successful in giving us access to Iranian facilities that we never had before , then he should tell us what his alternative would be
it 's like his plan to defeat ISIS
the only secret is that he has no plan
He says it 's a secret plan
we need to be more precise in how we talk about these issues
People around the word follow our presidential campaigns so closely , trying to get hints about what we will do
Can they rely on us ?
Are we going to lead the world with strength and in accordance with our values ?
That 's what I intend to do
I intend to be a leader of our country that people can count on , both here at home and around the world
to make decisions that will further peace and prosperity
also stand up to bullies , whether they 're abroad or at home
We can not let those who would try to destabilize the world to interfere with American interests and security"

cqs.cq: If his lack of a clear alternative to the deal with Iran undermines his credibility, can his vague claims of a secret plan to defeat ISIS be seen as a sign of weakness in leadership?
Does the President's approach of revealing a hypothetical secret plan as a means to criticize his opponent undermine the trustworthiness of his administration in international affairs?

If a nation's leader claims to have a secret plan to defeat a global threat, yet refuses to disclose details, does that not undermine trust and accountability in their ability to make informed decisions for the country?

If we're to hold leaders accountable for their promises, then can we expect transparency from the President regarding his alternative to the Iranian deal, especially when he claims to have a secret plan to defeat ISIS?

CLINTON_25.input:
CLINTON: "it 's important that we grip this and deal with it , both at home and abroad
here 's what we can do
We can deploy a half a billion more solar panels
We can have enough clean energy to power every home
We can build a new modern electric grid
That 's a lot of jobs
that 's a lot of new economic activity
 I 've tried to be very specific about what we can and should do
I am determined that we 're going to get the economy really moving again , building on the progress we 've made over the last eight years , but never going back to what got us in trouble in the first place"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on creating new economic activity through job creation and infrastructure development ends up causing a surge in consumption, thus offsetting the potential benefits of the clean energy and modern electric grid?

Does the deployment of a half a billion solar panels and the construction of a new modern electric grid align with the broader economic goals of reducing carbon emissions and mitigating the effects of climate change?

If deploying a half a billion more solar panels and building a new modern electric grid are presented as solutions to revitalize the economy, why isn't investing in renewable energy and infrastructure development seen as a long-term, rather than short-term, economic fix?
If Clinton's focus is on creating jobs and new economic activity, does that imply the administration's priority lies in short-term gains over long-term sustainability and environmental concerns?

CLINTON_37.input:
CLINTON: " Some of them I voted for
The biggest one, a multinational one known as CAFTA, I voted against
I hold the same standards as I look at all of these trade deals
let's not assume that trade is the only challenge we have in the economy
it is a part of it
I'm going to have a special prosecutor
We're going to enforce the trade deals we have, and we're going to hold people accountable
When I was secretary of state, we actually increased American exports globally 30 percent
We increased them to China 50 percent
 know how to really work to get new jobs and to get exports that helped to create more new jobs"

cqs.cq: What if the enforcement of trade deals and the accountability of individuals who break them, as proposed by the speaker, would cause a significant shift in the global market and affect the overall economic growth?

Can you provide evidence that your claims about increasing American exports by 30% globally and 50% to China during your tenure as Secretary of State are supported by verifiable data or official records?

If the Secretary of State's claims of increasing exports and job creation are accurate, would that not imply a more comprehensive approach to addressing the economy's challenges, rather than solely focusing on enforcing trade deals?

If the former Secretary of State increased exports to China by 50 percent, does that justify the lack of consequences for China's alleged trade violations, and should not the same accountability be applied to other nations like those involved in CAFTA?

CLINTON_39.input:
CLINTON: "I've been a senator, Donald
...
You haven't done it.
 I have been a secretary of state
And I have done a lot"

cqs.cq: What if being a senator and secretary of state is the cause that makes Clinton claim she has done a lot, but is it the case that doing so doesn't necessarily translate to effective leadership?
Can you provide evidence from your tenure as a senator or secretary of state that substantiates your claim of having "done a lot" in a manner comparable to a president's accomplishments?
If Clinton's experience as a senator and secretary of state are being highlighted as qualifications, why isn't her time as First Lady also being acknowledged?
If you claim you've done a lot as secretary of state, then how does that justify your claim of surpassing me when I've been a senator?

CLINTON_55.input:
CLINTON: "There are different views about what's good for our country, our economy, and our leadership in the world
it's important to look at what we need to do to get the economy going again
new jobs with rising incomes, investments, not in more tax cuts that would add $5 trillion to the debt"

cqs.cq: What if the focus on job creation and rising incomes ends up causing a surge in consumer spending, which in turn affects the country's economic growth?

Do you have any evidence from reputable economic or policy experts that support the claim that tax cuts are a more effective stimulus for economic growth than targeted investments in infrastructure and job creation?

If a nation's economic growth and stability are measured by investments and rising incomes, would prioritizing these over tax cuts align with the values of a country that prides itself on progress and social mobility?

If Clinton prioritizes economic growth over fiscal responsibility by advocating for investments while warning against tax cuts that increase debt, does this approach risk undermining long-term financial stability for the nation?

CLINTON_57.input:
CLINTON: "you have no plan
I have written a book about it. It's called "Stronger Together."
You can pick it up tomorrow at a bookstore
we need to have strong growth , fair growth , sustained growth
We also have to look at how we help families balance the responsibilities at home and the responsibilities at business
we have a very robust set of plans
people have looked at both of our plans , have concluded that mine would create 10 million jobs and yours would lose us 3.5 million jobs , and explode the debt which would have a recession"

cqs.cq: What if the promise of "Stronger Together" and the claim of creating 10 million jobs is a cause that would lead to a significant shift in public opinion, but does it also imply a potential effect of increased partisanship and polarization, thereby undermining the very foundation of fair growth and sustainable development?

Do you have any credible, peer-reviewed studies or data to support the claim that your economic plan would create 10 million jobs and that the opposing plan would result in a recession, as those assertions seem more reflective of campaign rhetoric than empirical evidence?
If a politician's written book is a comprehensive plan for economic growth, can we expect it to be more than just a sales pitch, or a genuine effort to address the country's needs?
If Clinton has a plan to create jobs and reduce debt, why does his proposed policy differ from the one he claims would be found in his book, "Stronger Together"?

CLINTON_66.input:
CLINTON: "what I have proposed would not add a penny to the debt
 your plans would add $ 5 trillion to the debt
What I have proposed would cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses
What I have proposed would be paid for by raising taxes on the wealthy
they have made all the gains in the economy
it 's time that the wealthy and corporations paid their fair share to support this country"

cqs.cq: What if Clinton's proposal to cut regulations and streamline them for small businesses actually causes a significant reduction in corporate tax revenue, would that undermine the plan to raise taxes on the wealthy and pay for the proposed measures?

Do you have any evidence to support the claim that the wealthy and corporations would indeed pay their fair share and that your proposed policies would not lead to a significant increase in taxes on the middle class?
If the wealthy and corporations have profited so greatly from the country, would it not be logical that they bear a proportionate share of the financial burden, just as any other citizen does?
If the wealthy and corporations are required to pay their fair share to support the country, then shouldn't they also be held accountable for their role in the economic gains they've made?

CLINTON_6_1.input:
CLINTON: "we are 5 percent of the world 's population ; we have to trade with the other 95 percent
we need to have smart , fair trade deals
We also , though , need to have a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions
the kind of plan that Donald has put forth would be trickle-down economics all over again
it would be the most extreme version , the biggest tax cuts for the top percent of the people in this country than we 've ever had
trumped-up trickle-down , because that 's exactly what it would be
That is not how we grow the economy
We just have a different view about what 's best for growing the economy , how we make investments that will actually produce jobs and rising incomes
we come at it from somewhat different perspectives
Donald was very fortunate in his life , and that 's all to his benefit"

cqs.cq: What if the economic policies of the 95% of the world's population, outside of the US, are more aligned with Clinton's views on economy growth, then would that not cause a significant shift in their influence on the global economy and affect US trade deals?

Do you have a scientific or economic source that supports the claim that a 5% population can effectively dictate fair trade deals and economic growth without considering the interests and perspectives of the remaining 95%?

If the US is only 5% of the world's population, and the wealthy 1% are the primary beneficiaries of the tax system, does that not represent a trickle-down effect, similar to the one Clinton criticizes in Trump's economic plan?

If the wealthy 5% of the world's population can afford to trade with the other 95%, shouldn't a tax system that rewards work and not just financial transactions be more inclusive and equitable for the majority, rather than just the privileged few?

CLINTON_6_2.input:
CLINTON: "He started his business with $ 14 million , borrowed from his father
he really believes that the more you help wealthy people , the better off we 'll be and that everything will work out from there
I do n't buy that
I have a different experience
My father was a small-businessman
He worked really hard
He printed drapery fabrics on long tables, where he pulled out those fabrics and he went down with a silkscreen and dumped the paint in and took the squeegee and kept going
what I believe is the more we can do for the middle class, the more we can invest in you, your education, your skills, your future
the better we will be off and the better we'll grow
That's the kind of economy I want us to see again"

cqs.cq: What if his wealthy upbringing and access to capital influenced his views on economic prosperity, rather than his experiences as a small businessman?

Does Clinton's assertion that the economy will "work out" if one focuses on helping wealthy individuals aligns with the economic principles of trickle-down theory, which has been widely criticized for its ineffectiveness in addressing income inequality?

If the speaker's business success was built on a foundation of privilege, such as borrowing $14 million from his father, how can he genuinely claim that his economic vision is built on helping the middle class rather than perpetuating his own privileged status?
If helping the wealthy alone can supposedly lead to a better economy, then why does Clinton's own background of inheriting wealth from his father not illustrate a more direct path to success?

CLINTON_85.input:
CLINTON: "let 's start the clock again , Lester
We 've looked at your tax proposals
I do n't see changes in the corporate tax rates or the kinds of proposals you 're referring to that would cause the repatriation , bringing back of money that 's stranded overseas
I happen to support that"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of repatriation, bringing back of money that's stranded overseas would cause the economic growth and development in the country to stagnate and affect the overall prosperity of the nation?
Do you have any specific evidence or policy changes from your administration that would justify the claim of repatriation of money that's stranded overseas?

If corporate tax rates remain unchanged, would the repatriation of money from overseas still be a priority when other pressing issues are left unaddressed, such as the widening wealth gap and economic inequality?
If Clinton sees no changes in the tax proposals that would cause the repatriation of money, does this imply that the administration's economic policies are ineffective?

CLINTON_87.input:
CLINTON: "I happen to support that in a way that will actually work to our benefit
when I look at what you have proposed , you have what is called now the Trump loophole
it would so advantage you and the business you do"

cqs.cq: Does the support for the "Trump loophole" by CLINTON imply a cause-and-effect relationship where her endorsement will inevitably lead to a favorable outcome for the business, thus raising questions about potential conflicts of interest?
Do you have a scientific source or policy document that supports the claim that the "Trump loophole" would inherently benefit your business interests?
If a politician like Clinton views a loophole as beneficial, why would she not also see systemic advantages for marginalized groups as a means to create a more equitable society?
If Clinton's support for the proposal is genuinely beneficial, then why would it still be considered a "loophole" that primarily advantages Trump?

CLINTON_92.input:
CLINTON: "it is
trumped-up trickle-down
Trickle-down did not work
It got us into the mess we were in , in 2008 and 2009
Slashing taxes on the wealthy has n't worked
a lot of really smart , wealthy people know that
they are saying , hey , we need to do more to make the contributions we should be making to rebuild the middle class
I do n't think top-down works in America
building the middle class , investing in the middle class , making college debt-free so more young people can get their education , helping people refinance theirâ€”their debt from college at a lower rate
Those are the kinds of things that will really boost the economy
Broad-based , inclusive growth is what we need in America , not more advantages for people at the very top"

cqs.cq: What if the trickle-down economic strategy advocated by the wealthy individuals Clinton mentions actually causes a widening of the wealth gap, rather than the inclusive growth she suggests?

Does your economic plan, Mr. Clinton, rely heavily on redistributive policies that fundamentally alter the traditional trickle-down approach, yet does it adequately address the systemic issues you claim it's meant to resolve?

If the middle class's growth and investments are what Clinton considers essential for the economy, wouldn't trickle-down economics, which benefits the wealthy, contradict her proposed solutions for economic recovery?

If trickle-down economics, which Clinton criticizes as ineffective, is indeed flawed, doesn't that imply that the wealthy's tax-cutting policies might have exacerbated the economic woes Clinton mentions?

CL_57.input:
CL: "Well, both sides of the transaction suffer as a result of ignoring moral hazard
because moral hazard is a natural part of the process of lending and borrowing
And if you suppress it, then in fact you're in a situation where the wealth that you look like you're generating is foolâ€™s gold, not real wealth at all."

cqs.cq: What if ignoring moral hazard in lending and borrowing leads to a situation where the perceived wealth is actually an illusion, causing the entire economic system to be built on shaky foundations?
Do you have any empirical evidence to support the claim that ignoring moral hazard in lending and borrowing inevitably leads to generating "fool's gold" rather than real wealth?
If a bank's profits can be considered illusory due to ignoring moral hazard, can the wealth of a community be considered similarly illusory when it's generated through exploitative systems?
If we're acknowledging the inherent risks in lending and borrowing, then why would we still consider the pursuit of profit as the primary motivator in financial transactions?

Doctor-Mom_205.input:
Doctor-Mom: "I would support a full ban of peanut products on any airline.
Peanut reactions can be life threatening.
An individual doesn't have to consume the product to have a life threatening reaction.
They can have contact or inhalation reactions.
Restricting to certain flights is not enough,
as residue can be rampant.
Providing buffer zones is a thoughtful gesture,
but from a practical point of view does not work.
With so many food choices available, why are peanuts a necessary choice?
I am a physician , and author on the subject.
I have free food allergy online support forums with 3000 members.
http://www.drmomsallergyrx.com/
I would be more than willing to work with you in any way on this decision making process.
The allergic community is so grateful that you are allowing our voices to be heard.
The decision you are considering could save many lives."

cqs.cq: What if the stringent enforcement of a complete ban on peanut products on airlines would inadvertently cause the economic burden of the industry to manifest and affect the livelihoods of thousands of workers employed in food production and transportation?

Do you, as a physician and author on the subject, have any personal or professional experience with peanut allergy patients that would suggest a blanket airline ban would be a more effective solution than targeted measures like buffer zones and allergen-friendly policies?

If the airline industry prioritizes accommodating passengers with peanut allergies by offering buffer zones and considering restrictions, why not take a more comprehensive approach and eliminate peanuts altogether, as advocated by a physician and expert in the field?

If you, as a physician and advocate, are prioritizing the lives of those with peanut allergies, shouldn't you also consider the potential consequences of completely banning peanuts on airlines, potentially affecting the livelihoods of thousands of workers in the industry?

Elmattador__92.input:
Elmattador: "you must have missed the GOP debates"
 < this message is answering to > 
Bigtwinkie: "This debate has honestly been making me uncomfortable
its been way too hostile
Its like listening to mom and dad fight in the kitchen while your hide under the covers in your room
 all they succeed at is making the entire panel seem unlikable
the democratic nominee will be bleeding votes no matter who wins"

cqs.cq: What if the increasingly divisive tone of the GOP debates causes voters to become disillusioned with the entire political process, ultimately affecting their willingness to participate in the democratic process?
Do you have a scientific basis for suggesting that the tone of a debate inherently makes a party nominee unlikable to voters?
Does the GOP's divisive debate dynamic effectively undermine the party's ability to present a united front and appeal to a broader electorate?
If the tone of the GOP debates is indeed as divisive as you've described, how can the party expect to appeal to a broad electorate and build a positive image for its nominee?

FoodAllergyMom_199_1.input:
FoodAllergyMom: "My child is 2 years old and he is severely allergic to peanuts, tree nuts, egg and milk.
My son has reacted to airborne particles from someone opening a bag of nuts near him.
My husband and I used to be world traveler's and dreamed of traveling with our son.
It is heartbreaking to think that our child will not get to experience the world, or if he does it may cost him his life.
What about when he gets older and his job requires him to fly across the country in a weekend?
Should he have to risk his life so he can work in his possible future dream job?
This is a disability, no question about it.
We are talking about being in the air with peanut particles being circulated through the cabin and possible no place to land for hours.
An EpiPen only last 15 minutes.
Peanut allergy is unpredictable.
The first reaction could be mild
and the second could cause your blood pressure to drop like a rocket, your throat to close up and your heart to stop beating."

cqs.cq: What if the widespread exposure to airborne peanuts in a flight environment causes his life-threatening allergic reaction, then should his future job prospects be prioritized over his immediate health and safety needs?

Do you believe that the severity of a child's food allergy should outweigh the potential benefits of traveling and exploring the world, particularly when the risks associated with airborne allergens can be mitigated with proper precautions and medical support?
If a child's life is at risk due to airborne peanut particles, why should he be expected to compromise his safety and health by flying in an environment where such exposure could be unavoidable?

If the risks associated with peanut allergy are so severe that they could potentially be fatal, why should the pursuit of a dream job, which requires frequent air travel, take precedence over the child's safety and potentially limit his future opportunities?

Frequent-Flyer_157.input:
Frequent-Flyer: "I have sympathy for those with peanut allergies,
but banning peanuts from flights via a DOT regulation seems to go too far.
Perhaps advocacy groups for those who are peanutallergic will approach the major carriers to voluntarily set aside seating blocks that are reserved for allergy sufferers, and nonsufferers who are willing to agree not to eat peanuts while sitting in that particular block.
As someone who suffers from a medical condition which requires me to carry my "rescue" medication with me everywhere I go,
I think that if the risk to an allergy sufferer is deemed to be significant, then they should
consider alternate travel methods other than flying,
ensure they have sufficient "rescue" medication to last the entire time they might be stuck in an aircraft,
they should wear appropriate clothing / face masks to minimize exposed skin and inhalation risk.
Requiring other passengers to forgo their "right" to eat peanuts so as to accommodate the "right" of allergy sufferers to fly seems a bit much,
particularly if the allergy sufferers don't fly often, anyway."

cqs.cq: What if the increased accessibility of peanut-free seating blocks, rather than blanket bans on peanuts, could cause a significant decrease in the risk to peanut allergy sufferers, thus affecting the necessity for restrictive regulations?

Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that the risk to peanut-allergic individuals is so significant that it necessitates altering flight policies and requiring other passengers to forgo their food choices?

If carriers can accommodate allergy sufferers with reasonable modifications, why can't they also make similar accommodations for passengers with medical conditions requiring emergency medication, rather than expecting others to sacrifice their rights?

If allergy sufferers can be accommodated by carriers through voluntary seating blocks, why should a blanket ban on peanuts on flights be implemented via a DOT regulation, rather than allowing passengers to make informed choices about their own food preferences?

Glblwrmingisfak__552.input:
Glblwrmingisfak: "What argument?
Nobody proposes common sense gun solutions
The DOJ over a decade ago already determined that an assault weapons ban won't do shit for addressing homicide rates in the US
It is not a solution for any of our problems
Bernie should know
he clearly isn't stupid"

cqs.cq: If the argument that assault weapons bans have been ineffective in addressing homicide rates, then why is there a persistent push for such policies despite the lack of empirical evidence supporting their efficacy?

Do you have any empirical evidence or expert opinions from reputable sources that support the claim that a decade-old DOJ determination conclusively dismisses the potential effectiveness of an assault weapons ban in addressing US homicide rates?

If the majority of the American public and the DOJ acknowledge that an assault weapons ban has limited effectiveness in reducing homicide rates, why should Bernie's stance on the issue be seen as anything other than informed by evidence rather than passion?

If the DOJ's findings show that an assault weapons ban has no significant impact on homicide rates, then does advocating for such a ban demonstrate a lack of understanding of the issue or a misguided attempt to address the problem?

HOLT_126.input:
HOLT: "Stop-and-frisk was ruled unconstitutional in New York
it largely singled out black and Hispanic young men"

cqs.cq: Does the ruling on Stop-and-frisk in New York effectively cause a disproportionate targeting of black and Hispanic young men, thereby affecting their civil liberties and social mobility?

Do you have a scholarly source that supports the claim that stop-and-frisk policing disproportionately targets black and Hispanic young men, and not other demographics, in the context of the New York ruling?

If police departments across the US can be held accountable for discriminatory practices like stop-and-frisk, why wouldn't similar accountability extend to institutions that perpetuate systemic inequalities in education, employment, or housing?

If the stop-and-frisk policy was deemed unconstitutional, doesn't that imply that it was a discriminatory and unjust practice, and shouldn't similar policies targeting specific racial groups be considered equally problematic?

HOLT_239.input:
HOLT: "Which leads to my next question
we enter our last segment here on the , still on the subject of securing America
On nuclear weapons , President Obama reportedly considered changing the nation 's longstanding policy on first use
Do you support the current policy ?
Mr. Trump , you have two minutes on that"

cqs.cq: What if the current policy on first use of nuclear weapons leads to a heightened risk of global conflict, then would that outweigh the potential benefits of maintaining it?

Do you believe that the historical precedent of nuclear deterrence and the strategic implications of first-use policy should be prioritized over the potential risks and uncertainties of changing it, Mr. Trump?
If the United States' stance on nuclear weapons' first use is akin to a delicate balance, should the decision-making process remain a partisan debate rather than a nuanced, bipartisan discussion?
If the US has historically been a proponent of non-proliferation and disarmament, wouldn't adopting a policy of first use undermine its moral authority and global leadership on nuclear arms control?

HOLT_94.input:
HOLT: "we 're talking about the burden that Americans have to pay , yet you have not released your tax returns
the reason nominees have released their returns for decades is so that voters will know if their potential president owes money toâ€”who he owes it to and any business conflicts
Do n't Americans have a right to know if there are any conflicts of interest"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency about the tax returns could cause a conflict of interest, potentially affecting the decisions made by the nominee and ultimately impacting their ability to serve the public interest?
Don't you think that transparency in tax returns is essential for ensuring a president's impartiality and accountability to the American people?
If nominees release their tax returns to maintain transparency and avoid conflicts of interest, why should a sitting president not be held to the same standard?
If tax returns reveal potential conflicts of interest, wouldn't transparency in the president's financial dealings also ensure accountability to the American people?

Helen__66.input:
Helen: "theyâ€™re not able to impose the right sort of levels
and within that bracket I would certainly put families who are living with very high levels of aggression and violence, who are terrorising communities
So, yes Iâ€™d agree with that
But I would also say that there are other families, where actually they do need a great deal of help
itâ€™s right to intervene
and actually you can help them get back on their feet and able to parent their children effectively"

cqs.cq: What if the aggressive families Helen mentions, who are terrorising communities, would cause their children to develop behavioral problems that affect their future employment and overall well-being?
Do you consider the notion of intervening in families with high levels of aggression and violence as a form of cultural or societal imposition versus a genuine concern for child welfare?
If families who are described as needing help due to high levels of aggression and violence are eligible for intervention, why would those exhibiting similar traits be denied the same support?

If Helen acknowledges that some families need intervention to stop their violent behavior, does that imply that she would also support holding accountable those families who are perpetuating such aggression and violence?

17th_knight__247.input:
17th: "They should get the coverage
They are here
they work
they are a part of this society
Fuck off with your xenophobia"
 < this message is answering to > 
reaper527: "now you have a field of democrat presidential candidates supporting it

cqs.cq: What if the widespread acceptance of undocumented immigrants receiving healthcare coverage might cause a significant shift in the political landscape, thus affecting the policy decisions of future presidential candidates?

Do you have any evidence that the assertion that a significant portion of the 2024 Democratic presidential candidates are advocating for providing healthcare coverage to undocumented immigrants is supported by a credible source, or is it based on anecdotal claims?
If illegal immigrants are entitled to healthcare under a Republican plan, would this not imply that their undocumented status no longer precludes them from being a part of society?

If a society that claims to value inclusivity and provide equal opportunities to all its members, why should xenophobic sentiments like the one expressed be tolerated when they directly contradict those principles?

AFCHF_154.input:
AFCHF: "DOT should set maximum tarmac delay trigger.
It then should apply to ALL AIRLINES and ALL CLASSES of AIRCRAFT.
The airlines need to make a legal committment (contract of carriage).
Deplaneing without CBP screening IS a viable option.
As a military member, I have done this many times during overseas contract flights.
I realize this is customs rather than airport security, but the concept is the same.
Allow passengers to deplane during gate holds,
but require them to remain in the immediate area.
This is no different than an openended delay prior to boarding."

cqs.cq: What if allowing passengers to deplane during gate holds without adequate screening increases the risk of security breaches, potentially causing more harm than the benefits of expediting their reboarding?

Do you have any empirical evidence or expert opinion from the aviation or transportation industry that supports the notion that deplaning without CBP screening is a viable and safe option for passengers, especially considering the potential security risks and logistical challenges?
If CBP screening can be bypassed by military personnel, why should it be any more necessary for other passengers to undergo screening, considering the security protocols are the same?

If passengers can safely deplane during gate holds without screening, then why should CBP screening be prioritized over deplaning, which could significantly reduce the overall delay and potential security risks?

AK-traveler_186.input:
AK-traveler: "Airlines should not be allowed to charge for items necessary because of factors out of the passengers control.
Seat size and configuration (arm and leg room) should be addressed as a health issue.
The inflight magazines show exercises passengers should do at their seats to prevent deep vein thrombosis
but there isn't enough room to do them.
And finally, I think it is unfair if not criminal and discriminatory to charge exorbinant fees for carrying your pet onboard with you.
The carrier is handled as a carry on bag solely by me,
the airline doesn't do anything
yet they carage $100 or more each way."

cqs.cq: What if the airline's lack of adequate seat size and configuration causes passengers to develop health issues like deep vein thrombosis, which in turn affects their overall travel experience and airline satisfaction?

Do you have a scientific study or expert opinion that supports the notion that airlines' seat configurations and charging for carry-on pet fees are not a legitimate health concern or discriminatory practice?

If airlines are required to provide a safe environment for passengers by offering exercises to prevent deep vein thrombosis, why can't they also provide sufficient space for passengers to perform those exercises, making seat size and configuration a matter of health and not a luxury feature?

If passengers are being told to exercise at their seats to prevent health issues yet the airlines are charging for necessary space, doesn't that suggest a contradictory stance on prioritizing passenger well-being?

AllergyDad_200.input:
AllergyDad: "As a parent of a child with severe lifethreatening allergies to peanuts and treenuts, the thought of getting on an airplane today is frightening.
So much so, that it is strictly avoided.
It is not worth risking my child's life to fly on an airplane.
A recent study reveals that 1 in 3 airplane reactions was anaphylaxis
(Allergic Living Magazine).
I don't like those odds.
The substitution of cashews, walnuts, or other tree nuts is not a viable option,
as they pose the same risks as peanuts.
A large number of people who are allergic to peanuts are also allergic to tree nuts,
plus they are typically processed in a plant that also processes peanuts.
If there were a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights, it would open the world to my son.
He didn't choose to be allergic,
but he is.
So true.
We are not talking about sensitivity, being offended, not liking the smell, etc.;
we are talking about life.
There are a lot of things that are banned from airplanes that can cause death to someone.
In the case of my son, a peanut can have the same result.
I urge the DOT to issue the ban,
and make traveling safe for everyone."

cqs.cq: Would the imposition of a ban on peanut and tree nut products on flights cause a significant reduction in the number of anaphylaxis cases, thereby making air travel safer for children with severe allergies?

Do you have any scientific data or expert opinions that support the claim that the risk of anaphylaxis from peanuts and tree nuts on flights is sufficient to warrant a blanket ban on these products, rather than more targeted safety measures?
If the DOT bans in-flight smoking due to health risks, why not consider banning peanut and tree nut products to protect passengers with life-threatening allergies?
If we consider banning items that can cause death, then why should peanuts and tree nuts, which pose a significant risk to allergy sufferers, be exempt from such a ban?

AngelComa__638.input:
AngelComa: "Funny, I thought he did good
They get timed responses
his plan is all there
He can't talk about everything in the plan
Must be how used you are to politicians saying things and not having a plan"
 < this message is answering to > 
Punchee: "That was a weird moment in American debate history. "Yo check my website. Shit's on there.""

cqs.cq: What if the politician's inability to articulate their plan is a cause for voters to question their ability to lead, which in turn affects the politician's chances of getting elected?
Do you have a credible source that supports the claim that a politician's ability to discuss their plan is a more significant indicator of their effectiveness than their past record?
If politicians often claim to have a plan but fail to deliver, does that not undermine the trust in their ability to provide timely and effective solutions?
If his plan is indeed 'all there', why does he lack the ability to clearly articulate it in public?

Antanagoge_104.input:
Antanagoge: "The airline industry can not be left to selfmonitor this.
Studies have shown that the quality of information from airline customer service department is highly variable and, in some cases, incomplete or inaccurate.
The psychological effects of this, combined with the risk of death, are significant.
Stories told by families of vacations never taken, of midair retraction of the promise by the airline that peanuts would not be served, of public humiliation of peanutallergic individuals and their family by airline staff, and of serious reactions in flight, abound."

cqs.cq: What if the variable and often incomplete information provided by the airline customer service department causes a lack of trust among passengers, potentially affecting their willingness to fly with that airline?
Do you have a scientific source that supports the claim that airline industry self-regulation is effective in mitigating the risks and inaccuracies associated with customer service information?

If airline passengers are often left to self-monitor their safety, why would that not also apply to their ability to access accurate and reliable information from airline customer service departments?
If the airline industry can't be left to self-monitor, then why are airlines still allowed to have such inconsistent and potentially life-threatening customer service practices?

Antanagoge_111.input:
Antanagoge: "The opponents of accommodations are well aware that studies have been published in the journals of the American Academy of Allergy Asthma and Immunology, the American Medical Association, and the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology, not to mention medical associations in other countries.
They can purchase full text access for themselves,
but they already have a prejudgment against the researchers and their conclusions,
so why bother?
There was a moment on the board when the moderators asked for a discussion of a hypothetical compromise position.
But those demanding funerals before entertaining even a compromise position muted that.
That is sad.
There are several others on the board with some good reasonable ideas.
It's fairly clear that meanspiritedness abounds, here
probably as a result of emphasis in current American politics on the potential for influence of minority interests and needs.
But some of the people on this board  calling for funerals before advancing the discussion  give new meaning to the Founders' fears of the tyranny of the majority."

cqs.cq: What if the preconceived biases of those opposing accommodations allow their prejudices to outweigh the credibility of scientific research, thus hindering a productive discussion and potential compromise on the issue?

Do you have any scientific evidence or credible sources to support the claim that the moderators' and participants' apparent disregard for a compromise position stems from a misguided emphasis on minority interests rather than a genuine concern for the validity of the research?

If medical experts and associations have access to and can critique studies on accommodations, why should the public not have the same access to these studies and be allowed to question the conclusions without being dismissed?
If the researchers' conclusions are already being prejudged and dismissed, does the accommodation's opponents' resistance to compromise stem from a genuine concern for facts or a pre-existing bias?

Antanagoge_227.input:
Antanagoge: "Peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin.
This study, "Recovery of peanut allergens from ventilation filters of commercial airliners," ? conducted "to help address whether peanutsensitive travelers are exposed to peanut aeroallergans during airline flights on which peanuts are served" ? resulted in the conclusion that "that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners. The most likely source of these allergens are the peanuts served during flights." ?
http://download.journals.elsevierhealth.com/pdfs/journals/00916749/PIIS0091674996811791.pdf"
 < this message is answering to > 
Mulder: "Apparently Samsmom is the ignorant one.
She attacks what she clearly does not understand.
If her child has a true peanut allergy that is so severe, he shouldn't be flying,
since her argument is that any contact with peanut dust or oil would cause anaphylactic shock.
Since that possibility is very real even outside an airline cabin,
she's making her own argument for living in a bubble.
Facts are stubborn things,
and one of those facts is that the air onboard an airliner is cleaner than in most public buildings,
so there's very little, if any, real risk involved in flying on a jet where peanuts have been consumed before or are even being served now.
Another stubborn fact is that you can be desensitized to peanut allergies,
but if you're unwilling to do it, don't blame others for not bending to your petty fears.
Nobody has studied this subject,
so there's no hard data.
But we do know that the air onboard an airliner is much cleaner than people think.
Only one confirmed death onboard an airliner has been reported,
but it may have been as far back as 1998,
and it was an Eastern European airline."

cqs.cq: What if the fact that peanut allergens can be eluted from ventilation system filters in commercial airliners, which are likely sourced from peanuts served during flights, causes a significant increase in the anxiety and fear of peanut-sensitive travelers, thus affecting their decisions to fly on airlines that serve peanuts?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that peanut allergens are the most likely source of exposure in commercial airliners, when the study you cited suggests it's a possibility, but not a confirmed fact?

If peanut allergens are indeed present in the recirculated air in the aircraft cabin, can the airlines and their passengers be held accountable for not taking measures to minimize exposure to these allergens, rather than solely relying on passengers to avoid flying with severe allergies?

If the risk of peanut allergens in the recirculated air of an aircraft cabin is so high that it warrants the mother's argument for living in a bubble, then why should her child's peanut allergy be the sole reason for restricting flight travel?

Antanagoge_239.input:
Antanagoge: "Is it really possible that all blindly partisan advocates of the peanut in this context eat peanuts and only peanuts?
That they are overtaken by such a compulsion to consume peanut while flying that they lose sight of all other priorities?
That they are unable to stop using their peanut  the one dragon they can't put to sleep  to create a sense of pleasure and comfort?
These sound like essential symptoms of disordered eating and addiction, which, in all likelihood, derive from some longstanding issues.
The remedy is to avoid the substance in question.... "just say 'no'" ? to your peanuts.
Serving/eating peanuts on airplanes has risen to the level of a public health menace, as had tobacco smoking.
Again, the only prudent course of action is to require that distribution of peanut on airplanes be discontinued."
 < this message is answering to > 
howie: "Mulder is right on point.
Most food allergies are completely imagined.
An overly anxious parent gets it in her head that little jimmy might have had a hive after someone had peanuts in his vicinity,
and now he's "deathly allergic".
Has ANYONE ever actually died on a plane from peanuts (other than by choking on them)?
I sincerely doubt it.
Peanuts are incredibly nutritious,
almost universally enjoyed,
and quite filling in a small serving.
Simply put, pound for pound there is no better food on the planet.
This whole antipeanut hysteria is ridiculous!
Leave my peanuts alone!
If you are one of the incredibly rare people that have an actual medically diagnosed severe allergy to this wonderful food, then you better never leave the house because peanuts are everywhere.
You certainly should not be flying."

cqs.cq: If people are so rarely actually dying from peanuts, then why are the concerns about peanuts on airplanes being a public health menace so overstated?

Do you have any scientific evidence to support the claim that peanuts are "incredibly nutritious" when the overwhelming majority of concerns surrounding peanuts in air travel are related to food allergies rather than nutritional benefits?

If the rarity of medically diagnosed severe peanut allergies is so low that it's considered a minority, why should the needs of such individuals be prioritized over the convenience of peanut-free flights for the majority?

If peanuts are indeed as nutritious and universally enjoyed as you claim, would it be reasonable to prioritize their availability on airplanes over the concerns of passengers with actual, medically diagnosed peanut allergies?

Bill_106.input:
Bill: "I run a retail business.
If I changed my prices every few minutes or hours like the airline does or charge my customers different prices on the same day.
They would probably never come back and call the better business bureau.
And they wonder why so much distrust and angry customers.
Recently I wrote to one airline that had a ticket price of around $198. but then listed the taxes at something like $400.00 extra.
I told them it was Bait and Add on.
Similar to some retail stores that Bait customers with low price and then Switch to higher priced goods.
It is illegal and called Bait and Switch.
The airlines or some ticket sellers are guilty of lies.
Taxes are never higher than the price of the ticket.
I spend hours trying to buy a ticket without getting ripped off.
It should not be this difficult.
And one way fare should be half of a RT not higher than RT.
hey force us to buy RT and then use only the one way portion."

cqs.cq: What if the practice of airlines and ticket sellers charging exorbitant fees, such as taxes, alongside the ticket price, causes consumers to feel deceived and distrustful, thus affecting their loyalty and trust in these businesses?

Do you have any evidence or expert opinion from the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or the airline industry that supports the claim that the practice you've described as "Bait and Add" is indeed a form of deceptive pricing, rather than a legitimate business strategy?
If airlines are found guilty of employing deceptive pricing tactics, why should consumers be expected to tolerate similar bait-and-switch practices in retail stores?
If airlines can be accused of "Bait and Switch" tactics by charging excessive fees, should consumers also not hold retailers accountable for deceptive pricing practices?

CF_29.input:
CF: "Yes, but what I'm saying is we shouldnâ€™t encourage it for ourselves either
Thatâ€™s my point.
And then finally, if I could just ask you, thereâ€™s a danger I think when you kind of say, â€œThe poor are the ones who suffer. The rich are the bad guys.â€
It is the case that some of the greatest examples of social progress over the years have come from well-off rich people, banks and so on, investing productively
Isnâ€™t the problem that the only thing the banks have done is kind of consumer credit?
What they should have been doing, what they could be doing, and what they havenâ€™t got the nerve to do, is not loaning enough
They should actually be taking more risk and giving more money out"

cqs.cq: What if the prevailing notion that wealth and privilege are the sole drivers of social progress leads to a misguided assumption that economic influence is the sole cause of positive change?

Do you think the notion that only the wealthy are capable of driving social progress is a misguided generalization, considering instances where philanthropy and innovation have come from diverse socioeconomic backgrounds?

If the wealthy individuals who have historically driven social progress can be seen as more than just "bad guys," why would the same label not be applied to those who are merely consumers of credit, rather than innovators of it?

If banks are indeed capable of driving social progress through productive investments, then why do you propose that they primarily engage in consumer credit instead of taking more risks and offering loans?

CF_46.input:
CF: "Yes, but I'm suggesting that that was a political strategy, a way of covering things up
All I'm saying is that I think the people who took the sub-prime mortgages were the beneficiaries â€“ and now the sufferers â€“ of what I was saying is a policy
When you think about it now, I actually find it frustrating when I'm trying to talk to people about the real state the economy is in
And people sort of assume like everything can just carry on, and all that you need is a kind of credit based consumer thing
â€œWell, do we have to have cuts? Do we have to have this? Do we have to have that?â€
And you do actually want to say, â€œMoney doesnâ€™t grow on trees.â€"

cqs.cq: What if the notion that money "grows on trees" is used to justify policies that benefit a select few, does it not perpetuate a cause-and-effect relationship where those in power maintain their privilege?
Do you have any evidence or credible sources that support the claim that policymakers' actions, rather than market forces, were the primary drivers of the sub-prime mortgage crisis?

If the current economic struggles are a result of systemic issues rather than individual failures, why should the burden of recovery solely fall on those who were not the primary beneficiaries of the policies that led to the crisis?
If the current economic situation is indeed as dire as you describe, why would your proposed solutions focus on credit and consumerism rather than addressing the systemic issues driving the crisis?

CLINTON_103.input:
CLINTON: "I think you 've seen another example of bait-and- switch here
For 40 years , everyone running for president has released their tax returns
You can go and see nearly , I think , 39 , 40 years of our tax returns
everyone has done it
We know the IRS has made clear there is no prohibition on releasing it when you 're under audit
you 've got to ask yourself , why wo n't he release his tax returns ?
there may be a couple of reasons
First , maybe he 's not as rich as he says he is
Second , maybe he 's not as charitable as he claims to be
maybe he does n't want the American people , all of you watching tonight , to know that he 's paid nothing in federal taxes
the only years that anybody 's ever seen were a couple of years when he had to turn them over to state authorities when he was trying to get a casino license
they showed he did n't pay any federal income tax"

cqs.cq: What if the lack of transparency regarding Clinton's tax returns causes a loss of public trust in his ability to manage the nation's finances?

Does the lack of publicly available tax returns from Donald Trump for the majority of his life undermine his claims of financial success and charitable contributions, potentially suggesting a pattern of tax avoidance?

If a candidate's reluctance to release tax returns is grounds for questioning their wealth and charitable claims, why should it not be a valid concern for a president who has a history of not paying federal income tax?
If he's been releasing his tax returns for nearly 40 years, why is the lack of transparency in his recent tax records a cause for concern rather than a consistent practice?

CLINTON_123_1.input:
CLINTON: "Race remains a significant challenge in our country
Unfortunately, race still determines too much
often determines where people live
determines what kind of education in their public schools they can get,
it determines how they're treated in the criminal justice system
We've just seen those two tragic examples in both Tulsa and Charlotte
we've got to do several things at the same time
We have to restore trust between communities and the police
We have to work to make sure that our police are using the best training, the best techniques, that they're well prepared to use force only when necessary
Everyone should be respected by the law, and everyone should respect the law
Right now, that's not the case in a lot of our neighborhoods
I have, ever since the first day of my campaign, called for criminal justice reform"

cqs.cq: What if the systemic issues you're highlighting, such as racial disparities in education and treatment by the law, cause a breakdown in trust and further exacerbate the cycle of violence, affecting community-police relations?
Does your proposed criminal justice reform also address systemic issues, such as implicit bias and socioeconomic disparities, that perpetuate racial inequality?

If the criminal justice system is often influenced by racial biases, would that not suggest a need for systemic reforms to address the inherent racial disparities in law enforcement and the justice process?

If the President emphasizes the need to restore trust between communities and the police, yet acknowledges that the law is not respected in many neighborhoods, does this imply a failure in the existing law enforcement and justice system rather than a lack of community-police relations?

CLINTON_123_2.input:
CLINTON: "I've laid out a platform that I think would begin to remedy some of the problems we have in the criminal justice system
we also have to recognize, in addition to the challenges that we face with policing, there are so many good, brave police officers who equally want reform
we have to bring communities together in order to begin working on that as a mutual goal
we've got to get guns out of the hands of people who should not have them
The gun epidemic is the leading cause of death of young African- American men, more than the next nine causes put together
we have to do two things
We have to restore trust
We have to work with the police
We have to make sure they respect the communities and the communities respect them
we have to tackle the plague of gun violence
which is a big contributor to a lot of the problems that we're seeing today"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on restoring trust between law enforcement and communities, while crucial, might inadvertently cause police officers to become less effective in addressing the gun epidemic due to a perceived shift in priorities?

Does the Honorable Clinton's emphasis on community-police collaboration and gun control as a means to address the root causes of crime and violence align with the actual statistics that show the majority of gun violence in African-American communities is perpetrated by individuals with a history of mental health issues or substance abuse rather than systemic police misconduct?

If the criminal justice system is plagued by systemic issues, would the same system not be responsible for perpetuating the epidemic of gun violence that disproportionately affects young African-American men?

If Clinton emphasizes that restoring trust and working with the police is crucial, but doesn't explicitly address the systemic issues driving police brutality, does this omission undermine her claim to truly address the root problems in the criminal justice system?

CLINTON_130_1.input:
CLINTON: "I've heard Donald say this at his rallies
it's really unfortunate that he paints such a dire negative picture of black communities in our country
the vibrancy of the black church
the black businesses that employ so many people
the opportunities that so many families are working to provide for their kids
There's a lot that we should be proud of and we should be supporting and lifting up
we do always have to make sure we keep people safe
There are the right ways of doing it
then there are ways that are ineffective
Stop-and-frisk was found to be unconstitutional
in part, because it was ineffective
It did not do what it needed to do
I believe in community policing
in fact, violent crime is one-half of what it was in 1991
Property crime is down 40 percent
We just don't want to see it creep back up
We've had 25 years of very good cooperation
there were some problems
some unintended consequences
Too many young African-American and Latino men ended up in jail for nonviolent offenses"

cqs.cq: What if the emphasis on community policing, rather than stop-and-frisk, causes a decrease in the perceived threat of crime, thereby reducing the racial profiling of black communities?

Do you think the effectiveness of community policing can be weighed against the potential long-term consequences of policies like stop-and-frisk, given the disproportionate impact on minority communities?

If the Clinton administration's policies were effective in reducing violent crime and property crime, why would their endorsement of community policing be considered a step back in addressing the systemic issues that led to mass incarceration of young African-American and Latino men?

If the black communities that Clinton praises for their vibrancy, businesses, and opportunities are indeed thriving, then why does she advocate for community policing that may lead to mass incarceration of young African-American and Latino men, as opposed to more effective and equitable solutions?

CLINTON_130_2.input:
CLINTON: "it's just a fact that if you're a young African-American man and you do the same thing as a young white man, you are more likely to be arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated
we've got to address the systemic racism in our criminal justice system
We cannot just say law and order
we have to come forward with a plan that is going to divert people from the criminal justice system
deal with mandatory minimum sentences, which have put too many people away for too long for doing too little
We need to have more second chance programs
I'm glad that we're ending private prisons in the federal system
I want to see them ended in the state system
You shouldn't have a profit motivation to fill prison cells with young Americans
here are some positive ways we can work on this
I believe strongly that commonsense gun safety measures would assist us
Right nowâ€”and this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobbyâ€”right now, we've got too many military- style weapons on the streets
this is something Donald has supported, along with the gun lobby
In a lot of places, our police are outgunned
We need comprehensive background checks
we need to keep guns out of the hands of those who will do harm
we finally need to pass a prohibition on anyone who's on the terrorist watch list from being able to buy a gun in our country
If you're too dangerous to fly, you are too dangerous to buy a gun
there are things we can do
we ought to do it in a bipartisan way"

cqs.cq: What if systemic racism in the criminal justice system causes young African-American men to be disproportionately arrested, charged, convicted, and incarcerated, and do you think this would affect the long-term prospects for rehabilitation and reintegration into society?

Do you have a scientific study or policy framework that supports the notion that diverting people from the criminal justice system through second chance programs is a more effective strategy for reducing recidivism and promoting rehabilitation than the current system of mandatory minimum sentences?

If a society that disproportionately arrests, charges, convicts, and incarcerates young African-American men for the same actions as young white men is considered a reflection of systemic racism, would the same societal factors also be at play when a young African-American woman faces differential treatment in the workplace due to her hairstyle?

If systemic racism in the criminal justice system disproportionately affects young African-American men, does it not also perpetuate a culture of unequal opportunity and fairness in the broader society?

CLINTON_147.input:
CLINTON: "New York has done an excellent job
I give credit across the board going back two mayors, two police chiefs
it has worked
other communities need to come together to do what will work
one murder is too many
it is important that we learn about what has been effective
not go to things that sound good that really did not have the kind of impact that we would want
Who disagrees with keeping neighborhoods safe
no one should disagree about respecting the rights of young men who live in those neighborhoods
we need to do a better job of working, again, with the communities, faith communities, business communities, as well as the police to try to deal with this problem"

citizen-s: "I strongly support cash compensation for bumping passengers with zeroprice tickets,

something that cries out for regulatory intervention

cd38_220_2.input:

when time allows, I make something to bring on the flight,

citizen-s_134.input:
citizen-s: "DOT's objective in setting this rule should be to ELIMINATE all bumping, not merely achieve some (unspecified) reduction.
Regardless of how many caveats an airline might state in its contract terms, passengers neither want nor deserve a ticket for an oversold seat.
Bumping is a purely economic device that treats passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, like so many other aspects of airline behavior.
From that objective, it follows that there should be NO cap on compensation
and that the financial penalty to the airline should be strong enough to prevent bumping, not just keep it at some arbitrarily "acceptable" level.
The 100% of the total ticket price for expected arrival within 2 hours later is reasonable.
Compensation for a longer delay should be the GREATER of 200% of the total ticket cost or the passenger's demonstrable outofpocket costs resulting from the delay
(a) including any higher priced air ticket from the same or another carrier at the same class, and lodging, meals and incidentals at average prevailing prices in that metro area,
and (b) with the obligation on the passenger to minimize those costs by arranging, with good faith help from the airline, an alternate flight or other means to get him or her to the destination as soon as reasonably practical."

cqs.cq: What if DOT's objective in eliminating bumping is compromised by setting a compensation cap at 100% of the total ticket price, thereby allowing airlines to continue prioritizing economic efficiency over passenger welfare?

Do you have a scientific source or empirical evidence to support the notion that passengers should be treated as economic units devoid of humanity, justifying the complete elimination of bumping without any cap on compensation?

If airlines treat passengers as economic units devoid of humanity, why should their compensation for bumping be limited to a fixed percentage of the ticket price, rather than a penalty that directly accounts for the actual harm and inconvenience caused?

If the primary goal of the DOT's rule is to eliminate all bumping, why would it be reasonable to cap compensation at 100% of the ticket price, rather than ensuring a stronger financial penalty to prevent bumping altogether?

 < this message is answering to > 
drgreg: "I believe airlines should be forced to fully reimburse confirmed passengers whenever the airline changes flight schedules after booking.
I frequently reserve flights up to one year in advance, in order to secure the lowest price and best seat.
I do this even though the airline will charge me $150 (plus fare difference) to change my itinerary for personal reasons once booked.
However, the airline frequently change flight schedules for confirmed passengers without compensation, nor consideration of passengers' plans.
For example, a trip to Europe on United Airlines has now been changed 7 times by the airline since I confirmed my reservation in December 2009.
The resulting changes have added nearly 5 hours to the total trip, plus I'm now required to leave at 3AM for the airport (instead of my original departure of 8AM), and I return after midnight, rather than a more reasonable 10:30PM.
In addition, United Airlines has not offered to waive the change fee, nor provide seats on alternate dates or airline partners.
If I'm required to pay exorbitant fees to the airlines to change my original itinerary, due to personal circumstances, then the airlines should also be required to compensate inconvenienced passengers in full AND provide satisfactory alternate travel arrangements comparable to the original flight schedule.
Perhaps this would force the airlines to recognize the hardships they create for passengers when schedules are revised after passengers have already received confirmed flights and make related travel arrangements."

 < this message is answering to > 
PracticalJo: "Take peanuts off of planes.
Safety first.
It is not only airborne particles that are problematical,
it is also the crumbs, whole peanuts that "get away" from the passenger (i.e., dropped on floor or in seat), and residue left behind on seats, seat belts, floors, tray tables and other surfaces.
Ingestion or contact can trigger severe reactions.
Take peanuts and items containing peanuts/peanut butter (e.g., trail mix, peanut butter crackers) off of airplanes.
This is all the airlines need to do.
Most airlines already have a suitable replacement snack.
Anyone with a severe allergy already has EpiPens or other medications.
Airlines need not provide these.
As an outsider to the airline industry, it is hard for me to say what level of cleaning currently occurs on an aircraft.
Obviously, on quick turnaround layovers, flight crews only have time for a cursory cleaning.

Javier_84.input:
